thread.title: At College: Offseason training pays dividends for New Bedford grad Paolo Tavares at UMass
thread.title_full: At College: Offseason training pays dividends for New Bedford grad Paolo Tavares at UMass

author: Brendan Kurie bkurie@s-t.com
title: At College: Offseason training pays dividends for New Bedford grad Paolo Tavares at UMass
text: Posted Oct. 17, 2015 at 6:12 PM Updated at 10:03 PM » Social News A lot of things came together for Paolo Tavares last spring. After dedicating himself to running over the winter, life seemed to click during his sophomore outdoor track season. When the semester concluded, he had even recorded the first 4.0 GPA of his career. That season he set new personal bests at distances of 1,500 and 5,000 meters, winning the 5K at the UMass Invitational. He reached his goal of a nine-minute steeplechase, taking second in the Atlantic 10 Conference and 11th at the IC4A Outdoor Championships. “I finally got a good base under my belt for the first time,” said Tavares. “In high school, I didn’t do a lot of miles compared to other runners because of wrestling. I never had a complete preseason campaign. Instead of taking the whole winter off, I listened to coach (Ken O’Brien) and did the whole winter, going 70-75 miles a week.” Now a junior, that success has carried over thanks to an increased summer training regiment and a new-found dedication to longer distances. Tavares has been among UMass’ top five cross country runners in all four meets so far this season, finishing as high as second on the team, while bettering his times from his first two seasons in all but one race. It helped that he took just two weeks off after spring track, instead of the four he took off in previous years, which often led to weight gains of 10-15 pounds. Beginning the first week of June, Tavares dedicated himself to a summer schedule that started with 45 miles a week and topped out at 75. He managed that while taking part in the BACCMD program at the UMass Medical Center in Worcester. He returned to New Bedford in July and his two-hour, 18-mile runs would take him from his home near Buttonwood Park to the UMass Dartmouth campus, up Hathaway to the airport and back past New Bedford High School. Before this past year, the longest he’d ever run was 12 miles, when he mirrored the course of the New Bedford Half Marathon in high school. In early September practices with the Minutemen, he immediately saw the benefit of his improved fitness level. “I haven’t fallen off any workouts yet,” he said. “That happened as a freshman about half the time. My sophomore year it happened two or three times. I’ve been with the guys in the front and feeling pretty good.” The payoff wasn’t evident in his first race this fall, when he finished 24 seconds slower than his sophomore year in the season-opening Minuteman Invitational. But then, at the Battle in Beantown, a week later, he took 50 seconds off his 2014 time and moved up 22 spots. During the Paul Short Invitational, he ran four seconds faster and finished 18 spots higher. At the New England Championship, he cut 14 seconds off his previous time and crossed the finish line 62 spots higher. The Beantown race was his best of the year, he noted, and said he used a new in-race strategy, racing out with the front pack and trying to hold on, rather than starting farther back and moving up throughout the race. “I tried to do things a little differently and race in front and take it from there,” he said. “I ran with our lead guy a little bit, and I just hung on and had a pretty good PR.” Tavares’ time at the Battle in Beantown was 25:21, the closest he’s come to the elusive 25-minute mark at eight-kilometers, which carries parallels with his academic quest for a 4.0 GPA, or his quest to slip under 16 minutes (5k) in high school (which he did once). After three semesters with a GPA between 3.7 and 3.92, the pre-med biology major finally achieved perfection in the second semester of his sophomore year. “Once you achieve that, you set a standard for yourself,” he said. “I’ve been focusing on my tests, trying to get eight hours of sleep.” Tavares plans on applying to medical school next year and said the BACCMD program gave him a cliff’s notes introduction to varying fields of medicine, from pediatrics to surgery to OBGYN. “You got to shadow the ER at UMass Medical to see if you can stomach things,” he said. “Luckily, I have a good stomach for stuff. It was definitely one of the biggest experiences of my life.” But before he becomes Dr. Tavares, Paolo hopes to lead the Minutemen to a top-four finish in the Atlantic-10 Conference, preferably with a top-15 showing individually. “We lost two seniors last year, so that put us in a hole, and we had another injury, so we had to fill in the gaps,” he said. “Luckily, we had a couple of freshmen who are sophomores now who stepped up and they’re consistent. I think we’re, hopefully, going to finish top four, or better.” As for Tavares going sub-25 minutes on an eight-kilometer course? “I think I’m close,” he said. FOOTBALL Senior Sean Murphy (Tabor/Mattapoisett) picked off his first pass of the season for WPI in a 29-21 win over Union on Oct. 10. He returned it seven yards, while also recording one tackle and returning one kickoff for 18 yards. Murphy has 24 tackles and 263 return yards on the year. ... Sophomore Richie Phillips (Old Rochester) ran for 67 yards on 13 carries for Mass. Maritime in a 46-39 loss to Western Connecticut on Oct. 10. He has 289 rushing yards on 64 carries in five games. ... Senior Brendan Smith (Dartmouth) recorded seven tackles and a sack for Mass. Maritime. Three of his tackles were for a loss and the sack was for -4 yards. Smith has 20 tackles and three sacks on the season. ... Junior Cody Stahmer (Wareham) caught three passes for 17 yards for Mass. Maritime against Western Connecticut. He has eight catches for 113 yards and two scores this year. ... Sophomore Jesse Noonan (Old Rochester) made a tackle for Mass. Maritime. ... Sophomore Joel Sodeinde (Dartmouth) made two tackles for Springfield College in a 35-13 win over Hobart on Oct. 10. ... Sophomore Kevin Nunes (New Bedford) caught three passes for 17 yards for Westfield State in a 35-7 loss to Framingham State on Oct. 10. They were Nunes' first catches of the season. WOMEN'S SOCCER Junior Morgan Stott (Dartmouth) allowed two goals in a game-and-a-half for Curry College. She made 15 saves but gave up two goals in a 2-0 loss to Endicott on Oct. 10, then made one save without allowing a goal in 45 minutes of action in a 4-0 win over Suffolk on Wednesday. Stott has 88 saves and a 0.76 goals against average through 14 games. ... Junior Kaitlyn Lima (New Bedford) scored two goals for Curry in a 4-0 victory over Suffolk on Wednesday. Lima has 10 goals and four assists on the season. ... Sophomore Hannah Cook (Dartmouth) notched a goal and an assist for Oberlin in a 3-2 loss to Rochester College on Oct. 10. It was Cook's first goal and fourth assist of the year. ... Sophomore Andrea Rego (Bishop Stang) scored the game-winning goal for Merrimack in a 1-0 victory over Bentley on Wednesday. It was Rego's third goal in her last six games. ... Senior Madison Catarius (Wareham) recorded her first point of the season with an assist for Nichols in Wednesday's 2-1 loss to MCLA. MEN'S SOCCER Redshirt freshman Klisman Sousa (New Bedford) earned his first collegiate point on Oct. 10 when he recorded an assist with a free kick in Providence College's 3-0 victory over then-No. 24 Xavier. Sousa sent the free kick into the right side of the six-yard box, where Mac Steeves headed it into the goal. ... Sophomore Nick Paine (Dartmouth) scored for the University of New England in a 4-3 loss to Western New England on Oct. 10. It was his first collegiate goal. ... Freshman Austin Eugenio (New Bedford) didn't allow a goal in 17 minutes of action during Johson & Wales' 7-2 win over Emmanuel on Oct. 10. It was his first varsity appearance. VOLLEYBALL Junior Kay Mullen (Fairhaven) was named Eastern Connecticut State's Athlete of the Week. In four matches over the last week she totaled 36 kills, five digs and four ace blocks. She had 10 kills and five digs in a 3-0 loss to Springfield on Oct. 9 and 11 kills and two ace blocks in a 3-2 victory over Westfield State on Oct. 10. Mullen is averaging 2.27 kills per set with a .206 hitting percentage. ... Junior Kat Mendes (New Bedford) totaled 28 kills, 30 digs, three service aces and two blocks in three matches this week for Salve Regina. She had 12 kills and 13 digs in a 3-1 loss to WPI on Oct. 10, after recording nine kills and 10 digs earlier in the day against Worcester State. Mendes is averaging 2.57 kills and 2.51 digs per set with a .095 hitting percentage. ... Freshman Katie Leidhold (Fairhaven) slammed down 30 kills with 34 digs, three service aces and a block in two matches for Franklin Pierce this week. She had 13 kills and 14 digs in a 3-1 loss to American International on Tuesday, then added 17 kills and 20 digs in a 3-2 victory over Stonehill on Thursday. ... In three matches for Simmons this week, junior Kat Guillotte (New Bedford) picked up 47 digs, three assists and six service aces. She had a season-high 23 digs in a 3-0 loss to Emerson on Thursday. Guillotte is averaging 3.96 digs per set. ... Freshman Erika Lamontagne (New Bedford) had three kills and one dig for Newbury in a 3-2 victory over St. Joseph on Thursday. She had a dig and an assist in a 3-0 win over Elms College on Oct. 10. FIELD HOCKEY Sophomore Katie Frade (Dartmouth) scored a goal in each of Wheelock College's two games this week, extending her scoring streak to four straight games. Frade scored once in a 3-1 victory over Elms College on Oct. 10 and again in a 4-1 loss to Becker on Wednesday. She has 10 goals and three assists this year. CROSS COUNTRY Sophomore Emma Robidoux (Fairhaven) finished 10th (18:51) for the University of New England during the James Early Invitational at Westfield State on Oct. 10. She was third on the team as the Nor'easters finished first in a field of 39 teams. ... Sophomore Bethany McMeekin (Apponequet) was 100th (21:05) for Westfield State at the James Early Invite. ... Sophomore Elizabeth Sullivan (Bishop Stang) finished 228th overall (20:40) for Assumption during the New England Championships on Oct. 10. ... Junior Ashley Pereira (Fairhaven) was 154th (21:00) in the women's JV race for Assumption at the New England Championships on Oct. 10. TENNIS Sophomore Jacquelyn Andrade (Bishop Stang) lost 7-5, 6-3 at No. 2 singles for Becker on Oct. 10 against Regis. She teamed up with Jennifer Lord to fall 8-2 at No. 1 doubles. Follow Brendan Kurie on Twitter @BrendanKurieSCT. To add a student-athlete to our watch list, please email bkurie@s-t.com. All statistics through Thursday. By Brendan Kurie
